review.title: Structuring Bodies of Evidence
review.abstract: In this article we present two ways of structuring bodies of evidence, which allow us to reduce the complexity of the operations usually performed in the framework of evidence theory. The first structure just partitions the focal elements in a body of evidence by their cardinality. With this structure we are able to reduce the complexity on the calculation of the belief functions Bel, Pl, and Q. The other structure proposed here, the Hierarchical Trees, permits us to reduce the complexity of the calculation of Bel, Pl, and Q, as well as of the Dempster's rule of combination in relation to the brute-force algorithm. Both these structures do not require the generation of all the subsets of the reference domain.

sections.text: 1 INTRODUCTIONEvidence Theory (Shafer 1976) is a well-known framework for presenting uncertainty in knowledge-based systems, but its application in practice is hampered by the important complexities associated with its manipulation, in particular the method used to combine evidence from independent sources, known as Dempster's rule of proof, may, at worst, require complexity of 22 "- 2n + t, with n representing the size of the reference. Algorithms proposed in the literature to reduce these complexities either limit the evidence itself or the reference domain of the variables they model. In this paper, we are interested in showing that some of the theoretical properties underlying the evidence bodies, the set of evidence bodies, can be used to produce algorithms that are efficient in situations where the data cannot be constrained.
